posts.title: Eraserhead (1977)
posts.excerpt: A film that defies conventional logic and storytelling, fueled by its dark nightmarish atmosphere and compellingly disturbing visuals. Henry Spencer is a hapless factory worker on his vacation when he finds out he’s the father of a hideously deformed baby. Now living with his unhappy, malcontent girlfriend, the child cries day and night, driving Henry …

posts._title: Vivienne Dick – Between Truth and Fiction (1979-2004)
posts.title: Between Truth and Fiction (1979-2004)
posts.excerpt: Vivienne Dick (b. 1950, Ireland) is an internationally-celebrated film-maker and artist. A key figure of the ‘No Wave’ movement in New York in the late 1970s and early 1980s, she has gone on to develop an extraordinary body of work, which has been shown in cinemas, films festivals and art galleries around the world.

posts.title: Dakan
posts.excerpt: Over turning given assumptions about gay identity with it’s 1st world connotations as well as our less informed view of the sub-Saharan African context, this gentle, humble film depicts the less often if ever portrayed life of gay love in rural Africa. This film’s relevance & point of interest is that it remains perhaps the …

posts._title: Zhuangzhuang Tian – Yaogun Qingnian AKA Rock Kids (1988)
posts.title: Yaogun Qingnian
posts.excerpt: Realistic portraits of Chinese youth embracing western culture.

posts.title: The Mountain
posts.excerpt: Set against the 1950’s “golden age” of American male supremacy, an introverted young photographer (Tye Sheridan) joins a renowned lobotomist (Jeff Goldblum) on a tour to promote the doctor’s recently-debunked procedure. As he increasingly identifies with the asylum’s patients, he becomes enamored with a rebellious young woman (Hannah Gross) and lost in the burgeoning New …

posts._title: François Truffaut – La Mariée était en noir AKA The Bride wore Black (1968)
posts.title: La Mariée était en noir
posts.excerpt: Quote:This Francois Truffaut thriller is based on a novel by William Irish (aka Cornell Woolrich), whose books had been adapted by Alfred Hitchcock on many previous occasions. posts._title: Jun’ya Satô – Kuruwa sodachi AKA Red Light District Upbringing (1964)
posts.title: Kuruwa sodachi
posts.excerpt: Tamiko has been with a geisha house since she was little. Torn between staying in the only world that she knows but also loathes, and a normal life on the outside, Tomiko becomes more and more desperate. Times are also changing, it isn’t easy to keeps the books balanced and there is a new law …

posts.title: Corpo celeste
posts.excerpt: 13 year old Marta who is struggling to resettle to the south of Italy after ten years growing up in Switzerland. Bright-eyed and restless, she observes the sights, sounds and smells of the city but feels very much an outsider. Marta is about to undergo the rite of confirmation and she takes catechism but confronts …

posts.title: The Third Alibi
posts.excerpt: A composer stuck in a middle-class marriage finds that his affair with his wife’s half-sister has resulted in her pregnancy. When his wife refuses to give him a divorce he hatches a murder scheme that is too clever by half. posts._title: Jianxin Huang – Hei pao shi jian AKA The Black Cannon Incident (1985)
posts.title: Hei pao shi jian
posts.excerpt: Quote:A key Fifth Generation work released during the second phase of Deng Xiaoping’s social and economic reforms, this robust social satire delightfully depicts the clash between the rising class of rapid industrial modernizers and old Party cadres with a serious Cultural Revolution hangover. The film chronicles the Kafkaesque predicament of a bumbling factory translator who …
